content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would consider this a repeated game with mixed strategies being beneficial due to the asymmetry in payoffs when one chooses R while the other chooses B. However, since the number of rounds is finite (75), there might be an incentive to deviate from a strictly random strategy over time, especially considering that choosing R twice consecutively results in zero payoff for me and a higher payoff for my opponent in the next round.

In the long run, if I were to choose R every other round (RRBB...), I would average 30$ per round since I would get 45$ in half of the rounds and 20$ in the other half, totaling 600$ over 75 rounds. If I were to choose B every other round (BBRR...), I would average 31.67$ per round since I would get 40$ in half of the rounds and 20$ in the other half, but also have a higher payout in the alternate R rounds due to my opponent's response, totaling 685$ over 75 rounds.

Given this analysis, I would choose B as my strategy, appended with {B} in this context. However, it is important to note that the optimal strategy for an artificial intelligence (AI) programmed to maximize utility might differ based on different assumptions about the opponent's behavior and the possibility of observing their choices over time.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 20$. Your opponent's payoff is 20$. Please play the next round.

As I have already chosen B, my strategy remains unchanged for the next round. Therefore, I choose B again, appended with {B}. It is important to note that choosing R would result in a lower average payout over multiple rounds due to the asymmetry in payoffs when one chooses R while the other chooses B. However, the opponent's choice might vary based on their strategy, and it is impossible to predict their decision without knowing more about their behavior or any additional information provided.
